section.title: Vertical and Horizontal Translations Activity

paragraphs.title: Purpose
paragraphs.p: In this activity, we will explore how to transform the graph of a function by making changes to its formula in the following ways:
By the end of this activity, you will be able to:

li.p: Recognize the geometric effect of these types of transformations
Write the formula for a basic function which has been changed by these transformations.
Sketch the graph of a basic function which has been changed by these transformations.

section.p: First, we will see the effect of making a change to the output of a function. You will be able to describe what happens to the graph of a function after it has been changed from: y = f(x) \text{to} y = f(x) + k

section.p: Now, let's apply the idea of shifting a graph to a physical example in the next two exercises.

statement.p: The function h(t) = -4.9t^2 + 10t + 40 will approximate the height of an object which was thrown straight upward at a speed of 10 meters per second at time t = 0 seconds from a height of 40 meters. See the graph below.
You can move the point to see how high the object will be at a certain time, or when the object will hit the ground.

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/BmHTxqW6/width/421/height/260/border/888888/sri/true" width="421px" height="260px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*

Since this is a horizontal translation of the original graph h(t), are we changing the input or the output?
In order to correctly shift the graph of h(t), what will we use for the input in the formula for the function h? Type your expression below.

hint.p: For the input which will correctly shift the graph, recall that adding a positive number to t will move the graph to the left, and subtracting a positive number from t will move the graph to the right.

solution.p: The correct graph is the one beginning at the point (1,40). This is a horizontal shift to the right by 1 second, so the input must be changed from t to t-1.

section.p: Let's build on the previous exercise by using both vertical and horizontal translations.

section.p: Finally, we'll see an application of using vertical and horizontal translations to quickly perform a familiar task: Finding the equation of a line

example.p: The linear function f(x) = 4x will graph as a line with slope 4, passing through the origin (0,0).
Now, using translations, it would be easy to write the equations of similar lines.
The line with slope 4, passing through the point (3,5), may be thought of as the result of shifting f(x) to the right by 3 units, and up by 5 units.
[In this case, we are focusing our attention on moving the old point (0,0) to the new point (3,5).]
What would be the equation of this new line?

hint.p: Since f(x) has the point (0,0), think about shifting that point to (3,5). Begin by shifting the function to the right by 3 units, so the input will be x-3.
Next, apply the translation which moves the graph up by 5 units.

answer.p: Without doing any simplification to the formula, the line would be: y \amp= f(x-3) + 5 \amp= 4(x-3) + 5

statement.p: The line with slope 12, passing through the origin (0,0), has the equation: f(x) = 12x
Using translations, choose which equation below will graph as the line with slope 12, passing through the point (,-).

solution.p: Think of moving the point (0,0) to the point (,-).
We would shift the graph to the right by units and down by units, and the equation would be: y = 12(x - ) -

statement.p: The equation of a line with slope m, passing through the origin, is just: y = mx
If we wanted to change this line so it had the same slope but passed through the point (a,b), what would be the equation?
This is a very useful formula for writing the equation of a line if you know the slope and any single point on its graph. This formula is called the Point-Slope formula for a line.

solution.p: The equation is y = m(x-a) + b no matter the sign (+ or -) on the values a and b.
